title: Assuming the following exothermic reaction at equilibrium: H2(g) + I2(g) <-> 2 HI (g). Which direction will the equilibrium shift if the temperature is decreased and allowed to reestablish the equilibrium? - Quora

response.answer_text: Equilibrium question …. H2(g) + I2(g) <=> 2HI(g) ……… ΔH is negative (exothermic) For an exothermic reaction we can envision “heat” as a product, then treat it like any other reactant or product when applying Le Chatelier’s principle. H2(g) + I2(g) <=> 2HI(g) + heat A decrease in temperature is like removing “heat”, which disturbs the system. Therefore, according to Le Chatelier’s principle, the system will shift to the right to make more heat and re-establish equilibrium. The partial pressures of H2 and I2 will decrease, and the partial pressure of HI will increase.

As the reaction is exothermic, according to Le- Chatelier principle, the equilibrium will move backwards that means the   rate of forward reaction will increase, if you decrease the temperature.        According to Le-chatelier principle... Low temperature is always favourable for exothermic reactions.

In an exothermic reaction, heat is a product. A temperature decrease removes some of that “product,” so the equilibrium should shift to the right to replace it. Thus, the new equilibrium mixture will contain a higher amount of hydrogen iodide than the equilibrium established at higher temperature.
